Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Rural: Querying Rich Uncertain Data in Real Time

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nowadays, a burgeoning amount of data is made available continuously. Example sources include various sensors, RFID, computer network traffic, phone conversations, and web searches. Much of this data is noisy, inconsistent, or even erroneous. Compared to deterministic data, uncertain data carries more information. Forcing uncertain data to be deterministic (e.g., by taking the expectations) can cause significant information loss in query results, possibly leading to wrong judgments for queries that aid decision making. Moreover, real-time decisions based on these data can have a significant impact on the quality of life, on the economy, and on our security. However, fast and real-time processing of uncertain data is a difficult problem. The broad goal of the RURAL (querying Rich Uncertain data in ReAL time) project is to provide techniques that make this query processing task feasible. To achieve this goal the project includes: (1) integrating data cleansing, distribution learning, and query processing through pipelining; (2) developing fast and online query processing algorithms on uncertain data; (3) providing a rich treatment of uncertain data distributions including compression, sharing, and gauging their reliability; (4) using predictive models to infer uncertain data distributions; and (5) answering top-k queries with consideration of typicality of results.

The RURAL project extends the state of art in real-time query processing of uncertain data for decision-making. It is used by the Kentucky Transportation Center for the application of dynamic traffic routing and control, and by the Biomedical Division at the University of Kentucky for real-time monitoring applications. The research results are integrated with education through class projects in Computer Science graduate courses at the University of Kentucky and tutorials at conferences. Further information on the project can be found on the project web page: http://protocols.netlab.uky.edu/~ge/projects/rural.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have produced some interesting research results and advanced the state-of-the-art in querying uncertain data in streams and stored relations. First, under the Monte Carlo query processing (MCQP) framework, we study the important but expensive JOIN queries. We devise an efficient JOIN algorithm. We also study how to adaptively determine the stopping of MCQP based on actual data. Additionally, we give a novel categorization of the semantics of JOIN on uncertain data. For each category, we propose efficient query processing algorithms or indexing mechanisms. Moreover, we extend the traditional query optimization with a “timing” component that determines when to execute what queries under multicore processors and real-time constraints. We study both offline and online optimizations, and the competitive ratio of the online optimizations.

Second, in online query processing of uncertain streams, we often must live with small samples. As we learn probability distributions from samples, different sample sizes render different levels of quality or accuracy in the learned probabilities. We quantify the accuracy information and study how to obtain it in query results. As decision making is based on predicates, we propose a new type of predicate called significance predicates that take the accuracy information into consideration. 

Third, it is well known that one challenging problem with probabilistic data is that typically it produces “too many” result tuples due to the exponentially many possible worlds with various probabilities; this is even worse when we have a ranking function since it may contradict the result tuple probabilities. This problem is more serious with real-time streams as the system may only be able to afford to process and present some “top” result tuples to users. We propose a novel approach (called a top-k oracle) for retrieving information of top-k results over uncertain data, which provides a best-effort estimate of the ground-truth top-k.

Fourth, we often need to rely on predictive models to infer missing or uncertain attributes from known attributes. Association rule mining can help on this; however, previous work on numerical attributes is unsatisfactory. We propose a novel divide and conquer two-phase algorithm, which is guaranteed to find all good rules efficiently. It is much faster than previous work and discovers significantly more useful rules.

Fifth, we study probabilistic substring and subsequence matching, which has diverse applications including the bioinformatics and biomedical domains. We propose novel query semantics and efficient algorithms which often achieve real-time performance. Finally, we study the more general problems of regular expression complex event processing in uncertain streams, where arbitrary correlations, graph streams, and parallel patterns are considered. For example, we use Markov chains to model correlations; we include both subgraph structures and event timing for graph streams; we propose novel semantics for parallel patterns and order-approximate matching.

The ideas studied in this project have broad applications in this big data era, including dynamic traffic routing, DNA and protein sequence pattern matching, ECG monitoring, emergency responses, business intelligence based on smartphones and sensors, and social network streams. A new graduate-level course is developed, and the materials of this project are also incorporated into a number of graduate and undergraduate courses. Graduate and undergraduate students have received valuable training in this project, including two Ph.D. students whose theses are based on the contents from this project and who are about to graduate. Finally, we have outreach activities involving high-school teachers, engineers, and physicians.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We have produced some interesting research results and advanced the state-of-the-art in querying uncertain data in streams and stored relations. First, under the Monte Carlo query processing (MCQP) framework, we study the important but expensive JOIN queries. We devise an efficient JOIN algorithm. We also study how to adaptively determine the stopping of MCQP based on actual data. Additionally, we give a novel categorization of the semantics of JOIN on uncertain data. For each category, we propose efficient query processing algorithms or indexing mechanisms. Moreover, we extend the traditional query optimization with a "timing" component that determines when to execute what queries under multicore processors and real-time constraints. We study both offline and online optimizations, and the competitive ratio of the online optimizations. Second, in online query processing of uncertain streams, we often must live with small samples. As we learn probability distributions from samples, different sample sizes render different levels of quality or accuracy in the learned probabilities. We quantify the accuracy information and study how to obtain it in query results. As decision making is based on predicates, we propose a new type of predicate called significance predicates that take the accuracy information into consideration. We propose novel query semantics and efficient algorithms which often achieve real-time performance. Finally, we study the more general problems of regular expression complex event processing in uncertain streams, where arbitrary correlations, graph streams, and parallel patterns are considered. For example, we use Markov chains to model correlations; we include both subgraph structures and event timing for graph streams; we propose novel semantics for parallel patterns and order-approximate matching. The ideas studied in this project have broad applications in this big data era, including dynamic traffic routing, DNA and protein sequence pattern matching, ECG monitoring, emergency responses, business intelligence based on smartphones and sensors, and social network streams. A new graduate-level course is developed, and the materials of this project are also incorporated into a number of graduate and undergraduate courses. Graduate and undergraduate students have received valuable training in this project, including two Ph.D. students whose theses are based on the contents from this project and who are about to graduate. Finally, we have outreach activities involving high-school teachers, engineers, and physicians. Last Modified: 10/20/2014 Submitted by: Tingjian Ge
